para.text: (UVE) is a computed byproduct of a least-squares adjustment, and should have a value close to one when the number of loops in a network is sufficiently large and the variances used to assign "weights" to measurements are realistic. The default variances assigned by Walls result in UVEs ranging from 0.2 to 2 for typical "good" cave surveys (see

). Very large values indicate abnormal inconsistency in the data. A UVE of 10 means we would have to multiply the assigned variances by 10 to obtain a new UVE close to one. Walls breaks the UVE into two components -- horizontal (UveH) and vertical (UveV) -- and displays them for each loop system. See also:
